p: The emergence of disease and the spread of epidemics depend on individuals’ behavior, the social structure in which they are embedded, and the political and civic environment that make particular social outcomes more likely for some than for others [ 63, 64]. When quarantine laws and social encounter restrictions (e.g., social distancing) are put in effect [ 65, 66], social scientists must be aware of the psychological, mental health, and economic aspects of these decisions. Cognitive science, brain and mind science, coupled with social and behavioral sciences, contribute insights into anxiety and loneliness associated with mental disorders under pandemic measures [ 67– 69].
